awd_titl_txt: Assimilating Computational and Mathematical Thinking into Earth and Environmental Science
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12).  This project will design, develop, and study the effects of instructional modules that integrate computational and mathematical thinking with the Earth and environmental sciences in grades 5-7. Three key elements of computational thinking (computational concepts, computational practices, and computational perspectives) will be interleaved with learning objectives in mathematics and the sciences at a pace that is grade-level appropriate.  As instructional modules are developed and refined, the project will: (1) Monitor effects on student learning and document changes in student reasoning about Earth and environmental science; (2) Develop and conduct teacher professional development activities that support integration of computational and mathematical thinking with the Earth and environmental sciences; (3) Investigate teacher experiences and perceptions of integrating computational thinking into instruction in order to learn how to support teachers in engaging in these instructional practices; and (5) Build a digital support platform to facilitate the development and use of the instructional modules, the teacher professional development activities, and the proposed research.

The project will employ a design-based research methodology focusing on continuous cycles of design, enactment, analysis, and redesign to accomplish project objectives.  The project will develop 12 curriculum modules, four at each grade level for grades 5-7, that will be designed around Earth and environmental themes identified by teachers.  Each module will include a set of tasks and activities for examining the organizing theme that also engage students with various programming resources, including Scratch, Molecular Workbench and Netlogo simulations.  Project participants will include 25 teachers and approximately 2,820 students from low-performing schools, and the project will pursue the following objectives: (1) Design and implement instructional modules that integrate computational and mathematical thinking into the Earth and environmental sciences in Grades 5, 6 and 7; (2) Study and refine the instructional modules to monitor effects on student learning; (3) Develop and conduct teacher professional development activities that support the integration of computational and mathematical thinking into the Earth and environmental sciences; (4) Investigate teacher experiences and perceptions of integrating computational thinking into instruction for the purpose of learning how to support teachers in implementing these instructional practices; and (5) Build a digital support platform to facilitate the development and use of the instructional modules and professional development and the proposed research. Project research will be guided by research questions relating to curriculum design and development, and student outcomes. Multiple level hierarchical linear modeling will be used to analyze assessment data from multiple treatment and comparison groups of students and teachers.  A range of student demographic data, teacher data, and school data will be used as predictor variables of test score outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
1. We have developed 12 instructional modules for the middle school students and teachers. 
  2. Ten of these modules integrate computational, mathematical and earth and environmental science thinking by engaging students in a series of investigation questions as they explore science content via computer simulations. These modules are: Gravity, Orbit,  Climate, Day night and seasons, Shadows and time, Lunar Phases, Rock Cycle, Water Cycle, Weather, and Greenhouse effect. Pre and post assessment are also developed for each module.  Online professional development materials are developed to train the teachers.
  3. Two of the modules are programming to learn JavaScript and Python programming languages. Students enjoy learning popular programming languages in addition to Scratch, block-based language. 
  4. We developed 17 interactive computer simulations using web technologies of JavaScript, CSS, and HTML5. A few simulations were written in NetLogo. We also developed 3 science projects for students to explore scratch programing. All of our interactive simulations can be freely accessed at https://acmes.online/view_simulation_links
  5. We have recruited a total of 67 science/math/technology teachers to integrate our modules into their classrooms. Over 3,000 students have participated in our project activities including formal classroom and summer learning camps. Our teachers came from local public school districts including Paterson, Bloomfield, Kearn, Orange, Wayne, and Livingston school districts.
  6. Our findings show specific principles for curriculum design that support the reciprocal relationship between math and science. That means that the science context supports students' mathematical learning and in turn the math content supports students' scientific learning.
  7. Our findings also show debugging can be used for supporting students' transdisciplinary learning. Coding for animation can also inspire students' interests and develop temporal and spatial concepts in computer system. 
  8. Our findings have been published in a total of 20 journal and conference papers at various math, science, and technology education venues. Our work was also presented in various national and international conferences. 
  9. Our dissemination efforts have showed to be successful. Our simulations and curriculum are used by teachers and researchers in our state as well as other states. For example, we have a middle and high school teacher from Massachusetts using our simulations. Another example is a researcher in technology education from Columbia who requested access to our curriculum after reading our published paper in 2021.
